appointment.title:
BOOK
APPOINTMENT
appointment.body: To arrange a meeting with the State Council, please complete the following appointment request form. Ensure all required fields are filled out accurately so we can process your request efficiently. You'll receive a confirmation email or phone call with the scheduled date and time.

appeal.title:
APPEAL TO THE
STATE
COUNCIL
appeal.body1: An appeal to the State Council is an administrative legal remedy allowing a party to challenge administrative decisions and acts. The State Council verifies whether administrative law was correctly applied and whether proper procedures were followed.
appeal.body2: The State Council is seized by a request from the parties or by a declaration filed with the Council. Appeals must be filed within the prescribed legal timeframes and must be confirmed by a petition with supporting documents.

report.subtitle: WE WOULD LOVE TO HEAR YOUR ISSUES

appealSteps.title: HOW TO FILL AN APPEAL
appealSteps.subtitle: Follow these steps to submit your appeal to the State Council

1.title: Prepare your documents
1.body: Gather the contested administrative decision, your identification, and any supporting evidence. Ensure all documents are legible and properly certified where required.

2.title: Draft your petition
2.body: Write a clear petition stating the facts, grounds for appeal, and the relief you seek. Include references to applicable legal provisions.

3.title: File with the Registry
3.body: Submit your petition and supporting documents to the Registry of the State Council within the prescribed legal timeframes. Obtain a receipt as proof of filing.

4.title: Pay applicable fees
4.body: Pay any required court fees at the designated office. Keep the payment receipt for your records.

5.title: Await notification
5.body: The Registry will notify you of the case number and hearing date. You may be required to serve copies to the opposing party.

haveQuestions.title: Have questions?
haveQuestions.body: Our team is here to help you understand the appeal process.

1.question: What is the deadline for filing an appeal?
1.answer: Appeals must generally be filed within two months of notification of the contested decision. Specific timeframes may apply depending on the type of administrative act. Consult the applicable legislation or contact the Registry for guidance.

2.question: Can I represent myself or do I need a lawyer?
2.answer: You may represent yourself before the State Council. However, legal representation is recommended for complex matters. The Registry can provide information on legal aid options if you qualify.

3.question: What documents do I need to include?
3.answer: Typically you need: the contested decision, your petition, identification, and supporting documents. The Registry provides a checklist upon request. Additional documents may be required depending on your case.

4.question: How long does the appeal process take?
4.answer: Processing times vary depending on case complexity and court workload. You will receive a hearing date after your case is registered. The Registry can provide estimated timelines for similar cases.

5.question: Can I withdraw my appeal?
5.answer: Yes. You may withdraw your appeal at any time before the final decision. Submit a written withdrawal to the Registry. Note that withdrawal may have implications for any related proceedings.

1.title: THE JUDICIAL YEAR OPENS AT THE STATE COUNCIL FOR THE 2025 - 2026 TERM
1.subtitle: HOME OF LAW & ORDER
1.body: This video covers the formal opening of the judicial year for 2025-2026. In the presence of President Felix Tshisekedi, the session brought together senior judges and legal officials.

2.title: STRENGTHENING JUDICIAL INDEPENDENCE AND ACCOUNTABILITY
2.subtitle: HOME OF LAW & ORDER
2.body: The STATE COUNCIL continues to uphold the principles of justice, fairness, and the rule of law. We are committed to ensuring transparency and integrity.

3.title: ADVANCING LEGAL EXCELLENCE IN THE DEMOCRATIC REPUBLIC OF CONGO
3.subtitle: HOME OF LAW & ORDER
3.body: Through rigorous legal training and adherence to international best practices, we strive to maintain the highest standards of judicial excellence.

offer.title: WHAT WE OFFER
offer.subtitle: We provide tailored legal solutions to meet your unique needs, ensuring your rights are protected and justice is served.

1.title: Supreme Judicial Authority
1.body: As the highest court of the ordinary judicial system, the State Council ensures uniform interpretation and application of law throughout the Democratic Republic of Congo.

2.title: Legal Certainty
2.body: Through our jurisprudence and decisions, we establish legal precedents that guide lower courts and ensure consistency in the application of justice.

3.title: Judicial Excellence
3.body: Our magistrates and counselors are selected based on merit, ensuring the highest standards of legal expertise, integrity, and commitment to justice.

4.title: International Cooperation
4.body: We actively participate in dialogue with international judicial bodies and maintain cooperation with French-speaking and African courts.

expertise.title: FIELDS OF EXPERTISE
expertise.subtitle: The STATE COUNCIL exercises jurisdiction over various legal matters as the supreme court of the ordinary judicial system.

1.title: THE FIRST PRESIDENT OF THE STATE COUNCIL

paragraphs.1: As the third-ranking member of the DRC's High Council of the Judiciary, the First President of the STATE COUNCIL, Brigitte Nsensele Wa Nsensele, donated blood on Thursday, February 27th, in solidarity with the victims of the Rwandan aggression in the eastern part of the country.
paragraphs.2: For every democratic Congolese citizen, contributing to the war effort is a civic duty. The judiciary is no exception.
paragraphs.3: For over three decades, the DRC has suffered aggression perpetrated by Rwanda and other negative armed groups, resulting in millions of deaths, tens of thousands of displaced persons, and a deplorable humanitarian situation.

paragraphs.1: Under the leadership of the First President, the STATE COUNCIL has embarked on comprehensive judicial reforms aimed at modernizing the judicial system.
paragraphs.2: The reforms include the digitalization of court records, implementation of case management systems, and training programs for judges and court staff.
paragraphs.3: These initiatives reflect the Court's commitment to transparency, efficiency, and accountability in the administration of justice.

paragraphs.1: The STATE COUNCIL actively engages with international judicial institutions and participates in global forums to share experiences.
paragraphs.2: Through partnerships with courts in France, Belgium, and other Francophone countries, the Court ensures it remains at the forefront of legal developments.
paragraphs.3: This international engagement strengthens the DRC's judicial system and enhances its capacity to deliver justice in accordance with international standards.

hero.title: UNDERSTANDING THE HIGHEST JURISDICTION OF THE ADMINISTRATIVE ORDER IN THE DEMOCRATIC REPUBLIC OF THE CONGO

intro.title: UNDERSTANDING THE HIGHEST JURISDICTION OF THE ADMINISTRATIVE ORDER IN THE DEMOCRATIC REPUBLIC OF THE CONGO
intro.body: Article 151 paragraph 1 of the Constitution of the DRC of February 18, 2006, establishes an administrative judicial system composed of administrative courts and tribunals with the supervision of the State Council. Article 82 of Organic Law No. 13/011-B of April 11, 2013 establishing the organization, composition and functioning of the administrative courts stipulates that there is existence of a State Council whose ordinary seat is located in the capital of the Democratic Republic of Congo. Its jurisdictional capacity can be exercised in another place. Historically, the State Council in this short presentation, traces its history and roots in our judicial institution. Created by Decree-Law on January 31, 1968, the State Council finds its distinct mark more than a century. Indeed, it was eight years after gaining independence in 1960 that the country established this State Council to regulate administrative appeals. It was only after a century in 2015 that the Supreme Administrative Court. This Court ceased to exist in the wake of the 2006 Constitution and its establishment, which declared null and void all provisions contrary and stipulated in its Article 223 that the judgments and orders rendered before the promulgation of the Constitution in force that has passed and tribunals into those passed in extreme by virtue greater specialization, and seated in case precedential, as instrument in the specialization of February 18, 2006, the Supreme Administrative Court ceased to exist definitively on April 11, 2013 when the Organic Law No. 13/011-B of April 11, 2013 establishing the organization, composition and functioning of the administrative courts. Pursuant to Article 151 paragraph 3 of the Constitution which establishes the regulatory authority for exercise of powers of the former Supreme Administrative Court. The administrative courts and tribunals comprising the administrative judicial system of Congo.

legal.title:
ACCESS THE MAIN LEGAL AND REGULATORY
TEXTS OF THE STATE COUNCIL

docs.1: Organic Law N° 13/011-B of April 11, 2013 containing the organization, composition and functioning of the ordinary jurisdictions
docs.2: Decree N° 13/046 of September 25, 2013 rules concerning the chambers of State Council
docs.3: Decree Law N° 13/018 relative to the remuneration and allowances to the magistrates

detail.title: Organic Law N° 13/011-B of April 11, 2013 containing the organization, composition and functioning of the administrative jurisdictions
detail.paragraph1: The content of this Law N° 13/011-B of April 11, 2013 containing the organization, composition and functioning of the administrative jurisdictions has been placed in a general administrative judicial context.
detail.paragraph2: Each of the articles of the Law is written across the key provisions of the Title I of the magistrates:

list1.2: CHAPTER II: Nomination and installation of the magistrates and clerks
list1.3: CHAPTER III: of the legal regime
list1.4: CHAPTER IV: Powers, guarantees and limits of the Magistrates

detail.paragraph3: It is governed by Title II of the State Council Article 81 to Article 95 that each article deals specifically with the State Council in the following chapters:

list2.2: CHAPTER II: Installation, composition of the State Council
list2.3: CHAPTER III: Different formations, functioning and personnel of the State Council

detail.paragraph4: The composition in article 82 provides how the State Council is composed, and lists the personnel which assists the magistrates and the auxiliary personnel attributions for the achievement of the administrative mandate.
detail.paragraph5: Article 83 provided for the attribution of the State Council, one of which is: Appeals in administrative matters; It exercises the discipline of judges and court auxiliaries in its jurisdictional capacity; It receives the oath of magistrates and court officers falling under the administrative jurisdiction; It gives the legal opinion in the presence of judges nominated or the jurisdictional authority. Article 84 provided for the composition of different sections and formation of the State Council; Article 88 provided for the attribution in the deliberation of the chamber, each chamber shall constitute a jurisdictional formation for achievement of the mandate of the State Council as to sit for different attributions only if the quorum is reached.
detail.paragraph6: The quorum required in the article is reached, when all chambers are composed as follows: the president or vice-president of chamber and two other magistrates, as well as a legal adviser and the Clerk.
detail.paragraph7: With regards to the judicial quorum in Article 89, each chamber may constitute a jurisdictional formation for the achievement of the mandate of the State Council and sit for different attributions only if the quorum is reached.
detail.paragraph8: The quorum required in the article is reached, when all chambers are composed as follows: the president or vice-president of chamber and two other magistrates, as well as a legal adviser and the Clerk. With the addition of the concerned interested party seated during the procedure with his assistance if need be and at the time of deliberations at the closed door, with participation of the Attorney General in the deliberations with participation of the clerk is done by the instruction of the matter.
detail.paragraph9: After reading and having the legal texts explained to the jurisdictions in this platform, you can request their service directly by contacting us by email or by telephone and therefore receive them.

hero.title:
SUGGESTED
REFORMS
hero.body: Modernizing the judicial system through strategic reforms that enhance efficiency, transparency, and access to justice for all Congolese citizens.

building.title: BUILDING A STRONGER JUSTICE SYSTEM
building.body: Following the 2006 Constitution, the STATE COUNCIL has embarked on comprehensive reforms to strengthen judicial independence, improve access to justice, and align with international standards. These initiatives focus on institutional strengthening, digital transformation, and capacity building.

initiatives.title: STRATEGIC REFORM INITIATIVES
initiatives.body: A comprehensive five-phase approach to modernizing our judicial system, ensuring excellence at every stage of transformation.

1.title: Institutional Independence
1.body: Strengthening judicial independence through constitutional safeguards and financial autonomy.

2.title: Access to Justice
2.body: Expanding legal aid services and establishing regional access points nationwide.

3.title: International Cooperation
3.body: Deepening partnerships with international judicial bodies for knowledge exchange.

4.title: Digital Transformation
4.body: Implementing modern case management systems and online jurisprudence databases.

5.title: Capacity Building
5.body: Continuous training for magistrates and advanced legal research capabilities.

hero.title:
INTERNATIONAL
RELATIONS
hero.body: In the context of the internationalization of law and justice, the STATE COUNCIL of the Democratic Republic of Congo is not isolated from this environment. It actively participates in the dialogue of judges by maintaining a high level of cooperation within the framework of the Association of Supreme Courts of French-speaking countries (AHJUCAF) and the African Association of Francophone Supreme Courts (AA-HJF).

networks.title: INTERNATIONAL JUDICIAL NETWORKS
networks.subtitle: The Court maintains privileged relationships with the leading associations of Francophone and African supreme courts

ahjucaf.name: Association of Supreme Courts Using French
ahjucaf.body: A platform for exchange and cooperation between Francophone supreme courts, facilitating judicial dialogue, sharing of jurisprudence, and strengthening institutional capacities across French-speaking jurisdictions worldwide.

aahjf.name: African Association of Francophone Supreme Courts
aahjf.body: A platform for exchange and cooperation between Francophone supreme courts, facilitating judicial dialogue, sharing of jurisprudence, and strengthening institutional capacities across French-speaking jurisdictions worldwide.

domains.title: INTERNATIONAL COOPERATION DOMAINS
domains.subtitle: Our international engagement translates into active participation in various initiatives aimed at strengthening the quality of justice and the rule of law

dialogue.title: Judicial Dialogue
dialogue.body: Regular exchanges on jurisprudence, best practices, and common challenges faced by supreme courts, fostering mutual learning and harmonized legal interpretation.

assistance.title: Technical Assistance
assistance.body: Technical cooperation for modernization of judicial systems, digitalization, and improvement of access to justice through shared experiences.

capacity.title: Capacity Building
capacity.body: Training programs, seminars, and workshops for strengthening the skills of magistrates and judicial personnel through international expertise.

forums.title: International Forums
forums.body: Active participation in international forums to contribute to the development of international and regional law and judicial standards.

collaboration.title: Interested in Collaboration?
collaboration.body: We are open to institutional partnerships and exchanges with other national and international jurisdictions committed to strengthening justice systems.

AUDIENCES
AND HEARING EXCERPTS

services.subtitle: Explore the divisions and offices that support the work of the State Council.

rooms.title: Rooms
rooms.body: Administrative and judicial rooms that organize deliberations and hearings.

council.title: Council
council.body: The office that coordinates policy and institutional governance.

registers.title: Registers
registers.body: Units that manage records, archives, and official filings.

chambers.title: The Chambers
chambers.body1: Each chamber handles specialized matters within its jurisdiction.
chambers.body2: Chambers sit in formations according to the applicable law.

rooms.title: Rooms and Chambers
rooms.body1: Rooms organize hearings and prepare case files.
rooms.body2: They ensure procedural compliance and scheduling.
rooms.body3: They support deliberations with administrative coordination.
rooms.body4: They ensure the smooth flow of cases to final decisions.

council.title: Council Office
council.body1: The Council Office ensures strategic coordination.
council.body2: It prepares plenary sessions and policy orientations.
council.body3: It oversees implementation of decisions and reforms.
council.body4: It supports communication and institutional relations.

registers.title: Registers and Archives
registers.body1: Registers receive and record filings and decisions.
registers.body2: They maintain archives for long-term preservation.
registers.body3: They provide certified copies upon request.
registers.body4: They manage the indexing and retrieval of case files.
registers.body5: They ensure confidentiality and integrity of records.
